text:
A few ideas:
1. Keep, Kill, Refresh strategies, specifically around what to do with old content that’s not driving business value.
2. Network effects & strategies for building credibility/expertise within content teams (especially when writing about technical/niche subjects)
3. Content + Design - How content people can be good partners to design teams & how to build better content together
4. Day in the life at different levels of content teams (e.g., how they spend time, balancing long-term vs short-term results/outputs, etc.)

elements.text: A few ideas:

text:
How to apply the content strategies that SaaS companies use to other industries, particularly small food and beverage brands. 

So basically, how to transpose an approach to content strategy that works really well into industries where they are not currently leveraging that approach.

text: Meaning, if we change nothing and just do what we did before, what happens. This is a really key thing to address because it communicates that we're focused on additive value, versus saying "we're up 20% year over year!" when you were up 30% YoY the year before.

elements.text: Meaning, if we change nothing and just do what we did before, what happens. This is a really key thing to address because it communicates that we're focused on additive value, versus saying "we're up 20% year over year!" when you were up 30% YoY the year before.

text: Yeah, that's so true, and I'm really aiming to show our team's real value. Thank you so much for everything!

text:
You need *dynamic content*. Many CMS' have Dynamic content options or plugins/themes that provide them.

Example: If you're using WordPress for your CMS, many themes (Divi, Elementor) have dynamic content options or you can create Blocks or Shortcodes. You add the *'refinance rate'* dynamic placeholder into your content where you want it displayed. From 1 single location, you change the rate.

In this article I wrote about Airtable automations, <https://on2air.com/resources/how-to-email-client-airtable-automations/#:~:text=Even%20More%20Powerful%20Automations|this particular section> is a dynamic global block (uses WordPress and the Divi theme). It's on multiple articles. It can be changed from any of those articles and will update on all of them.

It really depends on your setup for how to keep track of changes. You might have a custom post type that is specifically for 'Rates', and you have 'new loans', 'refinance', 'home equity', and you update them each day as they change (or connect to a finance API to automate it even more.)

text:
This is more of an event marketing question but was wondering if anyone could help:

I'm curious if any of you want to share some numbers related to webinar or online event attendance/registrants. With some previous webinars I ran we were getting like max 120 registrants and 20-25 actual attendees. To me, this seems like an average. But recently I've been attending some workshops/meetups that have 100-ish attendees. The chat is not usable but it makes for a great atmosphere.

Any numbers/benchmarks of this?

elements.text:
This is more of an event marketing question but was wondering if anyone could help:

I'm curious if any of you want to share some numbers related to webinar or online event attendance/registrants. With some previous webinars I ran we were getting like max 120 registrants and 20-25 actual attendees. To me, this seems like an average. But recently I've been attending some workshops/meetups that have 100-ish attendees. The chat is not usable but it makes for a great atmosphere.

Any numbers/benchmarks of this?

text: I'd say it really depends on your topic, promotion & speakers - I've been running webinars in different capacities for the past 6+ years, and have had anywhere between 100 to 17k registrants (personal record - last month). The more niche the topic (e.g. for SaaS, a new product demo), the less registrants you'll easily get. When it comes to attendance, my benchmark has been between 25 to 30%.

elements.text: I'd say it really depends on your topic, promotion & speakers - I've been running webinars in different capacities for the past 6+ years, and have had anywhere between 100 to 17k registrants (personal record - last month). The more niche the topic (e.g. for SaaS, a new product demo), the less registrants you'll easily get. When it comes to attendance, my benchmark has been between 25 to 30%.
